Top NATO General Acknowledges Changes In Alliance Are Needed "... very unfair to the United States." by Jeff Demers January 19, 2017 at 10:16am Share on Facebook 134 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
On the heels of President-elect Donald Trump’s assertion that NATO is “obsolete,” one of the alliance’s top generals, Denis Mercier, conceded in an interview this week that the alliance “has some structures that are obsolete.” 
Mercier, NATO’s Supreme Allied Commander Transformation General, says NATO wants to do more to battle the developing threat that extremists pose to the 28 member nations. 
“I took such heat when I said NATO was obsolete,” Trump told the London Times . “It’s obsolete because it wasn’t taking care of terror. I took a lot of heat for two days. And then they started saying, ‘Trump is right.'” Advertisement - story continues below Franklin Graham: It Wasn’t Donald Trump Who Divided This Nation 
Trump’s criticism in the London Times interview didn’t solely center on how NATO battles extremism. 
Echoing a common theme from his campaign, Trump highlighted that 23 of the 28 member nations were not paying their fair share to sustain the alliance. 
“A lot of these countries aren’t paying what they’re supposed to be paying, which I think is very unfair to the United States,” Trump lamented. Advertisement - story continues below 
The United States currently provides 72 percent of the funding for all of NATO, with only four other nations — Greece, Poland, Estonia and the U.K. — meeting the alliance’s funding guidelines: 
“With that being said, NATO is very important to me,” Trump said. “There’s five countries that are paying what they’re supposed to. Five. It’s not much.” 
Media outlets around the world have seized on Trump’s “obsolete” remark to try and find daylight between Trump and his cabinet nominees. 
On Monday, CNN reported “the clear gulf between Trump’s characterization of the alliance and that of his Cabinet nominees could set-up potential policy clashes with the White House.” Advertisement - story continues below
